Nature. 1996; 384: 644-648Crossref PubMed Scopus (1589) Google Scholar) and topology studies suggest that the catalytic domains of the synthases lie on the luminal side of the ER and are anchored to the ER membrane by hydrophobic side chains of amphipathic helices A–D (4Pico D. Loll P.J. Garavito R.M. Nature. 1994; 367: 243-249Crossref PubMed Scopus (1148) Google Scholar, 5Kurumbail R.G. Stevens A.M. Gierse J.K. McDonald J.J. Stegeman R.A. Pak J.Y. Gildehaus D. Miyashir J.M. Penning T.D. Seibert K. Isakson P.C. Stallings W.C. Nature. 1996; 384: 644-648Crossref PubMed Scopus (1589) Google Scholar). The topology models developed for PGIS and TXAS have their catalytic domains on the cytoplasmic site of the ER, opposite the orientation for PGHS in respect to the ER membrane. The substrate channels of all three enzymes opened at or near the ER membrane surface. This suggests that the coordination between PGHS and PGIS or TXAS in the biosynthesis of TXA2 and PGI2 may be affected by the anchoring of the enzyme in the lipid membrane. Results from our molecular modeling, site-specific antibody, and peptidoliposomal studies for TXAS, PGIS, and P450 2C1 have also indicated that the overall models predict the opening of the substrate access channels of PGIS and TXAS are immediately adjacent to the N-terminal membrane anchor domains and near the membrane surface. 2S.-P. So, D. Li, and K.-H. Ruan, unpublished data. This arrangement is consistent with the crystallographic identification of substrate recognition/docking sites in the N-terminal domains of P450BM3 and P450ter (32Peterson J.A. Graham-Lorence S.E. Ortiz de Montellano P.R. Cytochrome P450: Structure, Mechanism, and Biochemistry. 2nd Ed. Plenum Publishing Corp., New York1995: 151-198Crossref Google Scholar). These results led us to hypothesize that the N-terminal membrane anchor domains of PGIS and TXAS may have substrate recognition/docking sites, which facilitate or guide substrate-efficient access to the active sites. This hypothesis is supported from our current preliminary experiments in which the replacement of the N-terminal region of TXAS with the corresponding anchor segment from PGIS resulted in a significantly lower rate of TXA2 production using 30 and 60 s of incubation compared with the wild type of TXAS.2 The aim of this work is to characterize the interaction of the N-terminal membrane anchor domain of TXAS with its substrate in the membrane-bound environment. A way to evaluate the potential actions of the membrane anchor domain in facilitating the delivery of its substrate to its active site channel is to identify the substrate conformational changes induced by the membrane anchor domain. Our previous CD experiments (17Lin Y.Z. Wu K.K. Ruan K.H. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1998; 352: 78-84Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar) and NMR (18Ruan K.H. Li D.W. Ji J. Lin Y.Z. Gao X.L. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 822-830Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar) spectroscopic studies have found that the N-terminal membrane anchor domain of TXAS could adopt a stable helical conformation and incorporate it into phospholipid in DPC micelles, a membrane-bound environment, which suggest that the membrane anchor domain is likely able to mimic that portion of the protein function. This finding provided a basis for investigation of the interaction between the membrane anchor domain and the substrate in the membrane-mimicking environment. Due to the instability of TXAS substrate, PGH2 in solution, two PGH2 analogs, U44069 and U46619, with stable structures were used to replace PGH2 for the interaction. The conformation of U44069 changed by the presence of the membrane anchor domain of TXAS in DPC micelles (Fig. 7) provided evidence of the interaction between the TXAS domain and the PGH2 analog. Specifically, the change of the hairpin distance of U44069 from 8.25 to 4.93 Å (Fig. 7 C) suggested that the membrane anchor domain may play an important role in facilitation or guiding of its substrate to the active site channel of TXAS by reducing the three-dimensional size of PGH2, which allows the docking into the active site with lower energy. The interaction between U44069 and TXASLP1 was determined by the extra peak found in the NOESY spectrum of U44069 in the presence of the peptide (Fig. 8 C). This further suggested that the TXAS N-terminal membrane anchor segment is involved for the initial substrate recognition. The overall structures of U44069 and U46619 (Fig. 1) are identical to PGH2 except for one endoperoxide oxygen that was replaced with carbon at C-11 and C-9, respectively (Fig. 1). The three-dimensional structures of U44069 and U46619 determined provided complemented structural information for the modified endoperoxide of PGH2. The C-9 endoperoxide structural information is available from the structure of U44069, and the C-11 endoperoxide structure is provided from U46619. Combination of the solution structures of U44069 and U46619 provided full three-dimensional solution structural information for PGH2, which is difficult to characterize for its solution structure due to its instability in solution. The initial structure of PGH2 was first built using the Biopolymer program with the endoperoxide at C-9 and C-11. Due to the endoperoxide of U44069 at C-9, the constraints ofU44069 from the NOESY spectrum of proton distance from H1 to H10 (7 constraints) were used. As the position of endoperoxide is at C-11 forU46619, the constraints of proton distance from H8 to H2O were extracted from the NOESY spectrum of U46619 (11 constraints). A total of 18 constraints were used together for the structural calculation and the energy minimization, and dynamic studies were carried out using the Discover program within the Insight II package as described above. The constructed three-dimensional solution model of PGH2 was shown in Fig. 9. The simulated solution structure of PGH2 can be used as an initial structure for further structural characterization of the interaction between the synthases and PGH2. PGH2 is a common substrate for eicosanoid-synthesized enzymes including PGI2, PGE2, PGD2, and TXA2 synthases. Identification of the interaction between the N-terminal membrane anchor domain of TXAS with PGH2 analog implies the presence of the substrate interaction sites in the N-terminal membrane anchor domains of PGI2, PGE2, and PGD2 synthases. Characterization and comparison of the interactions of the different synthases with the common substrate is highly attractive for the future studies of understanding the mechanism of the biosynthesis of individual eicosanoid. Determination of solution structures of U44069 and U46619 also provides a basis to characterize the interaction of TXA2 and its receptor in structural terms because they are agonists for TXA2 receptor. By using the U44069 and U46619 conformation as basis, detailed studies for identification of the ligand-receptor interactions are under investigation in my laboratory.
